item.title: Using an Advanced Text Index Structure for Corpus Exploration in Digital Humanities
item.author: Tobias Englmeier, Marco Büchler, Stefan Gerdjikov, Klaus U. Schulz
item.description: Bibliography Blumer, A., Blumer, J., Haussler, D., McConnell, R., and Ehrenfeucht, A. “Complete inverted files for efficient text retrieval and analysis” . _Journal of the ACM (JACM)_ 34 (1987): 578-595. Büchler, M., Crane, G., Moritz, M., and Babeu, A. “Increasing recall for text re-use in historical documents to support research in the humanities” . In _Proceedings of 16th International Conference on Theory and Practice of Digital Libraries, (tpdl 2012):_ pp. 95–100 _Springer Berlin Heidelberg_ .

item.title: Decolonizing The Digital in the Classroom: Reflections on the Intersection of Colonial Latin American Art History and Digital Art History Pedagogy
item.author: Lauren G. Kilroy-Ewbank
item.description: “[D]igital media is not neutral: It impacts the represented information and the ways society interprets it” [kalay2008] . Introduction: Colonial Latin American Art and The Digital Digital visual media, such as images and videos, form an inescapable cornerstone of our lived experience. For those of us in higher education, the digital is altering not only how and what we research but also how and what we teach. In a similar vein as other specializations, the study of colonial Latin American art is being transformed.
